For reasons of volatility, or regulation, or other reasons. I'm open to theories.

11:21 am
BE

Anyway, here's Cazenove to summarise where we are.

BE

BP has reported Q3 2015 clean net income of $1,819m, which is 51%
above the market consensus of $1,205m (all consensus data sourced from
company) and 72% above our forecast of $1,059m. BP has averaged a Q3
consensus beat of +11% (Fig 1) so these results are clearly better than
trend in this respect. Core EBIT (a better measure of performance given
volatile tax rates) of $3,507m is 40% above market consensus of $2,500m
and 51% above our forecast of $2,329m. The key variance is upstream
with better than expected production ex-Russia +4.4% Q3-o-Q3 and
higher margins, helped by lower costs and strong gas marketing & trading
(not quantified). Q3 earnings of $1,819m are some way above the
quarterly earnings low from BP (Q1 1999 $658m), but Q4 earnings could
reach lower (Fig 2).

BE

By close yesterday, YTD 2015 BP had generated a total £ return of -2%
which beats the European sector (-5%), but is below the total return from
the FTSE All Share (+3%). Given the weak oil price backdrop with Brent
1-month trading $47/bbl, we expect the shares to open higher but lose
some ground over the day. In our view, Q3 results are less about what the
oil price has done to the business although that is revealing; they are more
about what management is going to do about it given the deteriorating
outlook for Q4 2015 / 2016. In this respect we note that BP (1) has raised
its restructuring charges from $1.5bn pre-tax by end 2015to $2.5bn by end
2016, (2) has given more explicit capex guidance post-2015 of $17-19bn
(JPMe $17bn).

11:23 am

Figure One, the quarterly earnings surprise chart, rather underlines my point.

BE

BE

Don't buy oil companies on consensus forecasts. Because they're wrong. Always.

PM

DB View: Q3 15 net income at $1.8bn was comfortably ahead of market at $1.2bn. Results were stronger across the business with E&P at $823m (CONS $350m) and Downstream at $2302m (CONS $1850m). Results are suggested to have seen some benefit from trading in E&P but much better margin capture in the downstream. Production at 2242mboe/d was comfortably ahead of DB 2149mboe/d. More significant than the results are the forward guidance on cash costs and capex. Cash costs are now seen as $3bn below those in 2014 with the company targeting an annualized $6bn controllable cash cost reduction by 2017 (off a DB estimated $25bn 2014 base). Equally after a guided c$19bn for 2015, capex is now set at towards $17-19bn over the near term as the company seeks to balance its cash flows and fund capex and dividends whilst continuing to drive growth from operating cash flow. Gearing at end period was 20% and debt $25bn with BP now expecting gearing to trade around the 20% band (was 10-20% whilst the, now resolved, Macondo uncertainties remained). With the 2014-15 $10bn divestment programme expected to conclude this year, further divestments of $3-5bn in 2016 are planned with $2-3bn p.a. envisaged thereinafter.

11:27 am

And some Barc

PM

The ONS preliminary estimate of Q3 GDP came in at 0.5% q/q (2.3% y/y), in line with our forecast and below consensus and BoE expectations (0.1pp and 0.2pp, respectively). The output breakdown shows value added grew by 0.49%, driven by services (+0.59pp contribution, Figure 1), while industrial was broadly muted (+0.04pp contribution) and construction detracted (-0.14pp contribution). Within services, the strongest contribution came from professional & support services (+0.18pp) and information & communication services (+0.13pp). Within the industrial sector, growth was pushed up by mining and quarrying (+0.05pp) while manufacturing contributed negatively (-0.03pp).

11:28 am
PM

This release suggests that the UK economy's momentum has begun to ease in light of increasing uncertainty and a weaker global environment, as we expected, but remains decent. The composition of value added remains excessively tilted towards services, with manufacturing posting a decrease in Q3. This decline echoes the EEF, the manufacturing representative body, which more than halved its manufacturing growth forecast in its Q3 Outlook Report released on Monday 7 September 2015; at the start of the year it was at 1.7% for 2015 whereas now it is at 0.7%. The EEF cited sterling strength and weak global demand for poor exports, noting that “exporters have had their worst quarter for new sales in six years”. Equally, PMI surveys for both services and manufacturing over Q3 found that there was “customer hesitation in placing new contracts linked to global economic uncertainty”.

· Latest business surveys have edged down but nonetheless point to continued decent growth until the end of the year and into 2016, barring a significant negative shock. In turn, we look for Q4 15 GDP growth to come in at broadly similar levels than Q3 15 (with upside risks from the Rugby World Cup). Looking further forward, we expect the Government’s planned significant fiscal consolidation to trigger more cautious behaviour by households, while firms are set to face a period of heightened uncertainty in the run-up to the EU referendum, thus likely resulting in reduced investment. As such, we project 2015 GDP growth at 2.4%, below 2014 (2.9%), while we project 2016 to continue to show ongoing slight moderation to 2.2%.

PM

Historically, manufacturing has been muted in its contribution to economic growth, with the bulk coming from services (Figures 2 and 3). Hence, it will be imperative to monitor closely services confidence so as to better gauge whether it remains resilient and thus overall activity with it.

PM

So no rate rises here for the foreseeable

Chemring Group PLC (CHG:LSE): Last: 155.68, down 70.82 (-31.27%), High: 162.00, Low: 131.00, Volume: 1.73m
11:43 am
PM

Discussions will be held with debt providers to negotiate amendments to the operation of covenants and the waiver of any event of default that may result from the 40mm contract delay

PM

BE

Yup. Emergency rights issue because of a "delayed" US ammo contract.

11:45 am
BE

Or, hang on, was it a delayed Middle East ammo contract that was meant to replace the US ammo contract?

BE

I forget the detail. Investec can probably help.

BE

Chemring’s unscheduled trading update highlights that, primarily due to a delay in the receiving necessary permits and export approvals for delivery of the new 40mm contract, it is unlikely to meet FY15 consensus revenue, which would result in a meaningful miss to profit expectations. New guidance is for £33m of operating profit, we had £49m. As a result of, but not wholly reliant on, the likely profit miss, the group has announced its intention to undertake a £90m Rights Issue in January. The terms have not been released.

New forecasts: Our headline forecasts reflect the newly available trading information and the proposed fund-raising, but as we do not yet know the terms of the Rights Issue, we have not attempted to factor in an increased share count. As such, FY16E and FY17E EPS and DPS estimates shown below and overleaf do not reflect the expected dilution.
FY15E: We reduce FY15E revenue to £390m from £432m, with the vast majority of the expected shortfall relating to 40mm contract, we understand. The company confirms that it is ready to ship the product when it is able to do so.
FY16E: We reduce operating profit by 12% to £50.7m (a £5.0m reduction), partially compensated by an assumed lower interest cost. Within the divisional mix, we increase our Energetics contribution whilst reducing Sensors & Electronics. Order cover is c.75% with £345m for delivery.
Balance sheet: The group expects to exit FY15E with net debt of £155-165m, which is only modestly higher than previous guidance and reflects the lack of a £12m advanced payment related to the 40mm contract. However, due to the EBITDA shortfall, the company is likely to be close to its banking and loan note covenants. The company will seek to negotiate amendments and a waiver.
Rights Issue: The Board’s aim is to reduce net debt/EBITDA to 1-1.5x as it believes this provides an appropriate capital structure. After costs, the £90m fully underwritten stand-by Rights Issue proposed would reduce leverage towards the bottom end of this range on our new forecasts. The terms of the Rights Issue will be released with the full year results on the 21 January.

The company has warned of delays to revenues from the 40mm ammunition
contract announced on 14 September 2015. As a result, it now expects
operating profit to be reduced by around £16m to £33m. The main issue for us
is the balance sheet as the company has warned that discussions will be held
with debt providers to negotiate amendments to the operation of covenants
and the waiver of any event of default that may result from the 40mm contract
delay. Our best guess at this stage is that the shares will fall to EV of around
1x2016 Sales of £450m, equivalent to 140p. We move our recommendation
from BUY to SELL.

undefined
BE

Also in the smalls, we have Dialight's long-awaited strategic review.

11:48 am
PM

http://www.investe...1510270700064834D/

BE

Old management gave the new chap a hospital pass, by letting the manufacturing side descend into chaos and hiring a load of 14 year olds as a sales force.

BE

Today we get the fix, which looks sensible enough but results in forecasts taking another step down.

11:50 am
BE

Canaccord incoming.

BE

Dialight has introduced its new strategic plan. It plans to:

Focus on the Lighting and Obstruction businesses, while managing the Traffic, Components and Vehicle businesses for value;
Expand into new sectors (e.g. institutional and transportation infrastructure markets) and focus more on geographies outside the US, starting with Europe;
Focus on corporate-wide sales in addition to factory-by-factory sales and sell more through partners (such as factory automation companies); and
Redesign its products based on common platforms and consider using outsourced manufacturers. Dialight's new product designs should reduce part count and manufacturing complexity significantly.
Through the above strategy, Dialight targets over 25% Lighting and Obstruction revenue growth, over 40% gross margin, over 15% EBIT and over 80% cash conversion by 2018.

The company also provided a Q3 trading update. Market conditions have become more challenging for Lighting, with continued weakness in O&G and reduced industrial capital expenditure. Lighting revenue growth in Q3 was 5% versus 24% in H1.

BE

We believe management's turnaround plans will increase Dialight's margin potential and scalability, diversify revenues and enhance growth opportunities.

We continue to believe the company is well positioned in a high growth market. The industrial lighting market remains less than 2% penetrated, according to the US Department of Energy, and Dialight's products continue to lead the market in efficiency and proven reliability, supported by unique 10 year product guarantees. Dialight's market shares and win rates are unchanged, despite the market downturn.

While we believe Dialight may generate earnings within the consensus range, we reduce our Adjusted Operating Profit to £6.0m from £15.5m in 2015E (Bloomberg consensus: £9.7m-£16.0m) and to £10.5m from £18.7m in 2016E (Bloomberg consensus: £16.0m-£21.4m). We assume Lighting revenue growth will slow further in Q4, resulting in no growth in H2, and we lower Lighting gross margin to 40% in H2 2015E from 44% in H1 2015. We forecast Lighting growth recovers to 15% and gross margin to 43% in 2016.

11:50 am
BE

The strategic review, trading update and high earnings growth lead us to focus on long-term value. Our sum-of-the-parts based target price now uses 2017E (previously 2016) multiples: 12x Adjusted EBIT for Lighting, 0.25x Sales for Components and 4x EBIT for Signals. We lower our target price to 600p from 660p.

BE

And Peel Hunt.

BE

Slow revenue growth in Q3 has heightened short-term earnings
risk again but management aspirations for FY18 set an attractive
target. The strategic review – to be detailed later – is pointing the
way to a slimmer and possibly more outsourced future. Our
earnings revisions reflect a tougher reality but margins and the
potential for growth remain attractive. Risks should reduce in the
next few months, but are substantial today, hence our Add
rating. Our TP has provisionally moved to 650p.

11:51 am
BE

Trading update and forecast changes
Following a weak Q3 (rev +5% in Lighting), we are reducing our forecasts for
clean PBT for 12m Dec’15/16/17E from £15.0m £18.7m £20.0m provisionally
to £5.0m £12.0m £18.0m (EPS 9.6p /23.9p /35.8p) ahead of today’s strategy
presentation, excluding restructuring costs, which should be largely non-cash.
Restructuring and strategic change
We already knew that 130 people, or 12% of the total indirect workforce, would
be leaving, reducing operating costs by greater than £3.0m in a full year (£1.0m in FY15,
together with cash costs of ~£1.0m), no further cuts have been reported as yet.
Management is focusing on restructuring the businesses into separable entities,
which gives much more flexibility on strategic options, most particularly sale.
Management is also working on a potential change in manufacturing strategy to a
predominantly outsourced model, enabling greater scale efficiencies and
enhancing the group’s ability to deal with growth.
Management’s 2018 target
Management is targeting 25% revenue growth and an EBIT margin of at
least 15% for FY18, which, depending on intervening growth, suggests that
PBT for Lighting and Obstruction alone could be £38m, greater than 75p per share.
Investors will clearly focus on the nearer term, but this does at least set a
management aspiration.
Dividend and Valuation
No dividend is likely before FY17, and we have pencilled in 8p for that year.
Dialight should be intrinsically cash generative – and is targeting over 80% cash
conversion in FY18. The key for us for valuation is whether Dialight could in fact
deliver closer to 50p EPS in FY17 rather than the 35p we are forecasting, driven
by better underlying growth and further cost savings. Our provisional TP is based
on achieving that at a rating of 13x to allow for risk (18x our actual forecast). We
will review this post the analyst meeting today.

Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 226.00, down 13.75 (-5.74%), High: 235.25, Low: 224.25, Volume: 670.96k

PM

(trc: -- good question. I wil ask)

BE

We downgrade to Hold. We believe Imagination's strategy is too skewed towards long term investment which could put the whole group at risk near term. Adj. EBIT margin is likely to fall to -4% in H1’16 from 27% in H1’12 as R&D continues to increase faster than revenue. R&D now accounts for 73% of revenue. Apple is slowing and licensing is likely to soften due to customer consolidation. We put through further downgrades and cut our TP to 250p from 275p.

11:55 am
BE

Apple is slowing

Apple is Imagination’s largest customer (34% of revenue) and has driven its growth. Dialog, a key Apple supplier, gave weak guidance for Q4 ($445m rev. vs consensus of $476m).

Licensing risk

The consolidation in the semiconductor sector reduces IP companies licensing revenue. We lower USD licensing revenue in FY'16 to 1% growth from 7% previously.

Another round of cuts
We cut both licensing and royalty forecasts. We reduce revenue by 2%/7% in FY'16/FY'17. The high operational gearing (1:10) leads to large EPS cuts.

Throwing in the towel

Shutting Pure (-33% margin) would put the group on a stronger financial footing but is unlikely to happen under current management. The IP business could be a target.

BE

BE

(@Mouselet: yup, actual radios, to put in your kitchen and listen to The Archers. A nice market but not, one would have thought, one that will grow into profitability.)

12:00 pm
BE

Headlines crossing the tape that Kazakhstan's looking at fining the BG-led Karachaganak consortium $2bn

BG Group PLC (BG.:LSE): Last: 1,030, down 20.5 (-1.95%), High: 1,048, Low: 1,029, Volume: 1.56m
BE

BG is joint operator of Karachaganak with a 29.25% stake.

12:01 pm
BE

With Eni, which has the same.

BE

After that it's Chevron (18%), LUKOIL (13.5%) and KazMunaiGas (10%).

BE

Kazakhstan was 14% of BG production in 2014, I'm told.

12:01 pm
BE

Olivetree gives us some snap analysis.

BE

Remember that the Kazakh’s have a history of this, whether in Karachaganak or Kashagan – they made a similar move in 2010. It should be remembered that the region is hurting a lot at the moment, they have downgraded their currency (the tenge) recently, and with an economy heavily dependent on oil the macro backdrop is tough for the country. Post the devaluation in August (and removal of its peg against the dollar), the currency fell greater than 20%. All global IOCs face these problems (eg YPF in Argentina) - it is a nature of the business to need to operate with NOC’s and not idiosyncratic to BG/. Shell will very likely be more philosophical than the market on this point.

This is likely a ploy to get more in terms of tax (legitimate or not) or better terms in a change of control in Karachaganak. Although clearly not positive (and it comes as no surprise to see the spread moving wider on the news) - any potential loss of value never is - we have talked with Shell extensively about Kazakhstan and it has always been stressed to us that this asset is not a core focus of the deal. Shell has intimated this many times in the past. Shell management have previously stressed to us that Kazakhstan is “not a deal breaker”. When we have probed on the pre-emption rights that the Kazak government have over the assets, Shell have always played down as as a non-event, joking to us in the past that “they can have it”.

When we have questioned them on the nature of the Kazakh assets, Shell said to us that, “If you look at the overall nature of the deal, the strategic rational lies in Brazil and Australia”. They have meet with all levels of government “up to the very highest”, and they are supportive of deal, but it has been unclear if they would exercise pre-emption rights. Whenever we have brought this topic up, they have always reiterated that other assets/regions are the focus here.
